div.p: C96/623, unit 864, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

It occurs to me honored Sir, that you would have the greatest convenience perhaps in sending off the seeds for the Burmese-authorities
See M to R. Rogers, 20 January 1896. by small parcels within the ordinary postal regulations, a plan, which I often myself adopt under si[milar]
obscured on p/c. ditto further on.
circumstance instead of sending by parcels-post, a method not secured by and for all countries.

I have therefore caused the seeds to be packed into several small lots within the Indian postal arrangements; […]wever you […] decide to send these seeds in one parcel, it would still be best to leave them in their present small lots within the one large packages,
sic.
as the seeds then will [be]
word left out.
all the more safe, against moisture, when travelling though the wet jungles on the long way […] upper Burma […] over for sowing in this years ra[…] season there, the seeds should arrive in Burma not later than february or early in march.
On 23 January 1896 Rogers, Secretary to the Premier, minuted: 'The Government Botanist The seeds have been duly forwarded and the Burmese authorities have been informed that 2 lbs more of Eucalyptus Citriodora will be forwarded as soon as possible. The Premier has decided that no charge is to be made to the Burmese Government for the seeds[.] I suppose the a/c will be paid by C.S. office'. On 24 January M forwarded the file to the Chief Secretary for his 'favorable consideration'.

div.p:
My official reply to your minute is with the set of papers now returned.
See M to R. Rogers, 20 January 1896.
An account for £3.15.0 was sent to Treasury on 28 January 1896. seems to have caused problems. On 10 April 1896 the Under Secretary, C. Topp, minuted: 'As […] from the terms of the Commissioner's minute [not included here] I think there may be some misapprehension as to this expenditure, before communicating with the Treasurer, I beg to […] this for the Commissioners' […] consideration. Though the claim has the Govt Botanist's certificate as the officer authorised to […] the expenditure, I do not regard the expenditure as expenditure of the Govt Botanists office; the expenditure may be regarded as general expenditure [… …] with […] relative with other Colonies. The seeds might have been bought directly from this office without the intervention of Baron Von Mueller, just as it may occasionally be necessary to buy books or maps which have been asked for by other Colonial Governments & which it would be unworthy of this Colony to charge for[.] I should be glad to know whether the Commissioners do not consider that such expenditure may be properly charged to the 'Incidentals' of this & the Premiers Office included […] I may point out that similar expenditure was similarly charged 13 August last & no objections was raised to it'.
